Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Bagchi, Prosenjit
Proposal Number: 1438255

The objective of the proposed work is to study the propulsion of biological cells that utilize their extremely deformable membrane to move. Cells can deform and extend a protrusion, called pseudopod, by streaming flow internally in a particular direction of the cell membrane, and the pseudopod is used to move the cell. This is a proposal to study the pseudopod-based propulsion of deformable cells from a fluid mechanical viewpoint using a combination of high-fidelity computational modeling, theoretical analysis and experimental measurements. In terms of impact on health, the project may provide a mechanistic understanding of how to inhibit propulsive mechanisms of malignant cells.

While fluid mechanical analysis of the streaming flow has been carried out recently in plant cells, which are non-deforming and non-propulsive, the relationship between the streaming flow, pseudopod dynamics, and motor activity is unknown in deformable cells. The co-PIs propose to develop a multiscale, 3D computational model of the interface deformation driven by molecular motors. The model will predict simultaneously the dynamic cell shape, the flow field, and motor activity. In parallel, micro-PIV experiments will be performed in live amoeboid cells to extract the 2-component quasi-instantaneous intra-cellular velocity field. Using analysis of the simulation and experimental data, the nature and origin of the streaming flow in deforming cells, and its relation to pseudopod dynamics will be explored.
This award by the Fluid Dynamics Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Computational Mathematics Program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most biological cells are highly motile. Cell motility is essential for life to exist. Cells utilize a diverse means of motility. Many cells utilize flagella and cilia to swim in a liquid environment. On the contrary, many cells utilize extreme deformation of the cell body to migrate. Examples of the latter type of migration are abundant in nature and in human body. Amoeba bacteria commonly found in nature entirely rely on such deformation-induced migration. In the human body, leukocytes, nerve cells, epithelial cells utilize such migration mode, as well as the cells during embryonic development, and metastatic cancer cells. These cells move by creating slender projections of their body, called pseudopods, which are generated by the actin-myosin protein complex inside the cells. The growing actin filaments inside the cells push the cell membrane outward, creating a pseudopod. These pseudopods are highly dynamic, and they grow, bifurcate and retract. The repeating cycles of pseudopod growth, bifurcation and retraction propel the cells forward.

Deformation-driven cell motility is a complex multiscale process, and involves cell's internal protein machinery, cell deformation, and surrounding environment. In terms of intellectual merit, we have developed a 3D, multiscale computer model to simulate motility of deformable amoeboid cells incorporating these three elements. We have studied cell motility in unbounded liquid medium, as well as in presence of obstacles. We studied the influence of cell deformability, protein diffusivity, cytoplasmic and extracellular fluid viscosity on the pseudopod-driven motility. Our results show that cell deformability strongly affects the cell's motile behavior. Specifically, we found that cell speed increases with increasing deformability. This result is in agreement with the notion that metastatic cells are more deformable than benign cells, and that deformability is a potential biomarker for malignancy. We also provide detailed mechanistic understanding of pseudopod behavior by which the deformable cells attain higher speeds. Specifically, we found that the number of pseudopods increases with increasing deformability, and these pseudopods tend to remain focused near the front of the cells. As such more deformable cells can maintain unidirectionality in their migration even in absence of an external cue. We published these results in journals Physics of Fluids, and Soft Matter -- where our work was highlighted as front and back cover articles, respectively. Broader impacts were achieved primarily through research. The work has impact in areas of mechanics, computer simulation, and biology. A PhD student was supervised in thesis research, and high school students were exposed to hands-on research experience in the area of computer modeling for complex bio-engineering problems. Results were disseminated via journal publications and conference presentations.


Last Modified: 02/13/2019
Modified by: Prosenjit Bagchi

Many cells utilize flagella and cilia to swim in a liquid environment. On the contrary, many cells utilize extreme deformation of the cell body to migrate. Examples of the latter type of migration are abundant in nature and in human body. Amoeba bacteria commonly found in nature entirely rely on such deformation-induced migration.
